page.title: 06LOCAL HISTORY 2
page.content: ON THE EAST BANK OF THE OUSE THE BENINGBROUGH ESTATE, GRANTED BY HENRY VIII TO JOHN BANNISTER, WAS INHERITED BY HIS SON-IN-LAW. RALPH BOURCHIER BUILT A LATE ELIZABETHAN MANOR HOUSE BY THE OUSE.LATER, IN 1716, JOHN BOURCHIER OCCUPIED A NEW QUEEN ANNE BAROQUE HALL DESIGNED AND BUILT ON HIGHER LAND BY ARCHITECT-CARPENTER WILLIAM THORNTON OF YORK. THE ESTATE AND HALL LATER PASSED THROUGH THE DAWNAY FAMILY AND THE LAST RESIDENT OWNER WAS LADY CHESTERFIELD WHO DIED IN 1957.THE HALL AND PARK ARE NOW NATIONAL TRUST PROPERTY.A SPECIAL FEATURE IS THE MAGNIFICENT CARVING IN THE STATE ROOMS. RESTORED IN 1979 IT IS A MAJOR TOURIST ATTRACTION.IT STANDS IN 146 HECTARES OF PARKLAND AND 2.8 HECTARES OF GARDEN, WHICH INCLUDE UNUSUAL TREES AND RARE SHRUBS,AND ATTRACTIVE DISPLAYS OF PERENNIALS.
